mn137:0.2.eng: The Analysis of the Six Sense Fields

mn137:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn137:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn137:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn137:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of the six sense fields.
mn137:2.1.comm: Here and at MN 139:2.1 the Buddha only announces that he will teach the analysis, but proceeds to give the recitation passage as well. Contrast with MN 133:6.2 and MN 138:4.2.

mn137:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn137:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn137:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn137:3.1.pli: “‘Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni veditabbāni, cha bāhirāni āyatanāni veditabbāni, cha viññāṇakāyā veditabbā, cha phassakāyā veditabbā, aṭṭhārasa manopavicārā veditabbā, chattiṃsa sattapadā veditabbā, tatra idaṃ nissāya idaṃ pajahatha, tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo sevati yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahati, so vuccati yoggācariyānaṃ anuttaro purisadammasārathī’ti—
mn137:3.1.eng: “‘The six interior sense fields should be understood. The six exterior sense fields should be understood. The six classes of consciousness should be understood. The six classes of contact should be understood. The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood. The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood. Therein, relying on this, give up that. The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group. Of all meditation tutors, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those fit for training.’

mn137:3.2.eng: This is the summary recital for the analysis of the six sense fields.

mn137:4.1.eng: ‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’

mn137:4.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:4.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:4.3.eng: There are the sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

mn137:4.4.eng: ‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’

mn137:4.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:4.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:5.1.eng: ‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’

mn137:5.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:5.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:5.3.eng: There are the sense fields of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn137:5.4.eng: ‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’

mn137:5.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:5.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:6.1.eng: ‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’

mn137:6.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:6.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:6.3.eng: There are eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.

mn137:6.4.eng: ‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’

mn137:6.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:6.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:7.1.eng: ‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’

mn137:7.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:7.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:7.3.eng: There is contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

mn137:7.4.eng: ‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’

mn137:7.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:7.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:8.1.eng: ‘The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood.’
mn137:8.1.comm: Also at MN 140:10.1, SN 36.22:2.15, and AN 3.61:12.1. Outside of this context, upavicāra is only found in AN 6.52, where women are “preoccupied” with adornments and thieves are “preoccupied” with a hiding place.

mn137:8.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:8.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:8.3.pli: ‘Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā somanassaṭṭhānīyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhānīyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhānīyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati.
mn137:8.3.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

mn137:8.4.eng: Hearing a sound with the ear …

mn137:8.5.eng: Smelling an odor with the nose …

mn137:8.6.eng: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

mn137:8.7.eng: Feeling a touch with the body …

mn137:8.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya somanassaṭṭhānīyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati, domanassaṭṭhānīyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati, upekkhāṭṭhānīyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati.
mn137:8.8.eng: Becoming conscious of an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

mn137:8.9.pli: Iti cha somanassūpavicārā, cha domanassūpavicārā, cha upekkhūpavicārā, aṭṭhārasa manopavicārā veditabbā’ti—
mn137:8.9.eng: So there are six preoccupations with happiness, six preoccupations with sadness, and six preoccupations with equanimity. ‘The eighteen mental preoccupations should be understood.’

mn137:8.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:8.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:9.1.eng: ‘The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood.’

mn137:9.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:9.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:9.3.pli: Cha gehasitāni somanassāni, cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni, cha gehasitāni domanassāni, cha nekkhammasitāni domanassāni, cha gehasitā upekkhā, cha nekkhammasitā upekkhā.
mn137:9.3.eng: There are six kinds of domestic happiness and six kinds of renunciate happiness. There are six kinds of domestic sadness and six kinds of renunciate sadness. There are six kinds of domestic equanimity and six kinds of renunciate equanimity.

mn137:10.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of domestic happiness?

mn137:10.2.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyānaṃ rūpānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ manoramānaṃ lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ paṭilābhaṃ vā paṭilābhato samanupassato pubbe vā paṭiladdhapubbaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ samanussarato uppajjati somanassaṃ.
mn137:10.2.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the worldly pleasures of the flesh. Happiness arises when you regard it as a gain to obtain such sights, or when you recollect sights you formerly obtained that have passed, ceased, and perished.

mn137:10.3.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati gehasitaṃ somanassaṃ.
mn137:10.3.eng: Such happiness is called domestic happiness.

mn137:10.4.eng: There are sounds known by the ear …

mn137:10.8.pli: manoviññeyyānaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ …pe… somanassaṃ.
mn137:10.8.eng: Ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the worldly pleasures of the flesh. Happiness arises when you regard it as a gain to obtain such ideas, or when you recollect ideas you formerly obtained that have passed, ceased, and perished.

mn137:10.9.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati gehasitaṃ somanassaṃ.
mn137:10.9.eng: Such happiness is called domestic happiness.

mn137:10.10.eng: These are the six kinds of domestic happiness.

mn137:11.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate happiness?

mn137:11.2.pli: Rūpānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati somanassaṃ.
mn137:11.2.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

mn137:11.3.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitaṃ somanassaṃ.
mn137:11.3.eng: Such happiness is called renunciate happiness.

mn137:11.4.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds …

mn137:11.8.pli: dhammānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati somanassaṃ.
mn137:11.8.eng: ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

mn137:11.9.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitaṃ somanassaṃ.
mn137:11.9.eng: Such happiness is called renunciate happiness.

mn137:11.10.eng: These are the six kinds of renunciate happiness.

mn137:12.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of domestic sadness?

mn137:12.2.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the worldly pleasures of the flesh. Sadness arises when you regard it as a loss to lose such sights, or when you recollect sights you formerly lost that have passed, ceased, and perished.

mn137:12.3.eng: Such sadness is called domestic sadness.

mn137:12.4.eng: There are sounds known by the ear …

mn137:12.5.eng: There are smells known by the nose …

mn137:12.6.eng: There are tastes known by the tongue …

mn137:12.7.eng: There are touches known by the body …

mn137:12.8.pli: manoviññeyyānaṃ dhammānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ manoramānaṃ lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ appaṭilābhaṃ vā appaṭilābhato samanupassato pubbe vā appaṭiladdhapubbaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ samanussarato uppajjati domanassaṃ.
mn137:12.8.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasing, connected with the worldly pleasures of the flesh. Sadness arises when you regard it as a loss to lose such ideas, or when you recollect ideas you formerly lost that have passed, ceased, and perished.

mn137:12.9.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati gehasitaṃ domanassaṃ.
mn137:12.9.eng: Such sadness is called domestic sadness.

mn137:12.10.eng: These are the six kinds of domestic sadness.

mn137:13.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate sadness?

mn137:13.2.pli: Rūpānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti:
mn137:13.2.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations:

mn137:13.3.pli: ‘kudāssu nāmāhaṃ tadāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharissāmi yadariyā etarahi āyatanaṃ upasampajja viharantī’ti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpayato uppajjati pihapaccayā domanassaṃ.
mn137:13.3.eng: ‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’ When you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations like this, sadness arises because of the yearning.
mn137:13.3.comm: Also at MN 44:28.6. That “dimension” (āyatana) is Nibbana (Ud 8.1:3.1, SN 35.117:8.2).

mn137:13.4.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitaṃ domanassaṃ.
mn137:13.4.eng: Such sadness is called renunciate sadness.

mn137:13.5.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds …

mn137:13.9.pli: dhammānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti:
mn137:13.9.eng: ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations:

mn137:13.10.pli: ‘kudāssu nāmāhaṃ tadāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharissāmi yadariyā etarahi āyatanaṃ upasampajja viharantī’ti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpayato uppajjati pihapaccayā domanassaṃ.
mn137:13.10.eng: ‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’ When you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations like this, sadness arises because of the yearning.

mn137:13.11.pli: Yaṃ evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitaṃ domanassaṃ.
mn137:13.11.eng: Such sadness is called renunciate sadness.

mn137:13.12.eng: These are the six kinds of renunciate sadness.

mn137:14.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of domestic equanimity?

mn137:14.2.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjati upekkhā bālassa mūḷhassa puthujjanassa anodhijinassa avipākajinassa anādīnavadassāvino assutavato puthujjanassa.
mn137:14.2.eng: When seeing a sight with the eye, equanimity arises for the unlearned ordinary person—a foolish ordinary person who has not overcome their limitations and the results of deeds, and is blind to the drawbacks.

mn137:14.3.pli: Yā evarūpā upekkhā, rūpaṃ sā nātivattati.
mn137:14.3.eng: Such equanimity does not transcend the sight.

mn137:14.4.eng: That’s why it’s called domestic equanimity.

mn137:14.5.eng: When hearing a sound with the ear …

mn137:14.6.eng: When smelling an odor with the nose …

mn137:14.7.eng: When tasting a flavor with the tongue …

mn137:14.8.eng: When feeling a touch with the body …

mn137:14.9.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjati upekkhā bālassa mūḷhassa puthujjanassa anodhijinassa avipākajinassa anādīnavadassāvino assutavato puthujjanassa.
mn137:14.9.eng: When knowing an idea with the mind, equanimity arises for the unlearned ordinary person—a foolish ordinary person who has not overcome their limitations and the results of deeds, and is blind to the drawbacks.

mn137:14.10.pli: Yā evarūpā upekkhā, dhammaṃ sā nātivattati.
mn137:14.10.eng: Such equanimity does not transcend the idea.

mn137:14.11.eng: That’s why it’s called domestic equanimity.

mn137:14.12.eng: These are the six kinds of domestic equanimity.

mn137:15.1.eng: And in this context what are the six kinds of renunciate equanimity?

mn137:15.2.pli: Rūpānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati upekkhā.
mn137:15.2.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

mn137:15.3.pli: Yā evarūpā upekkhā, rūpaṃ sā ativattati.

mn137:15.4.eng: That’s why it’s called renunciate equanimity.

mn137:15.5.eng: When you’ve understood the impermanence of sounds …

mn137:15.9.pli: dhammānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati upekkhā.
mn137:15.9.eng: ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

mn137:15.10.pli: Yā evarūpā upekkhā, dhammaṃ sā ativattati.

mn137:15.11.eng: That’s why it’s called renunciate equanimity.

mn137:15.12.eng: These are the six kinds of renunciate equanimity.

mn137:15.13.eng: ‘The thirty-six positions of sentient beings should be understood.’

mn137:15.14.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:15.14.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:16.1.eng: ‘Therein, relying on this, give up that.’

mn137:16.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ; Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:16.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:16.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāni cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni tāni nissāya tāni āgamma yāni cha gehasitāni somanassāni tāni pajahatha, tāni samatikkamatha.
mn137:16.3.eng: Therein, by relying and depending on the six kinds of renunciate happiness, give up and go beyond the six kinds of domestic happiness.

mn137:16.4.pli: Evametesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametesaṃ samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:16.4.eng: That’s how they are given up.

mn137:16.5.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāni cha nekkhammasitāni domanassāni tāni nissāya tāni āgamma yāni cha gehasitāni domanassāni tāni pajahatha, tāni samatikkamatha.
mn137:16.5.eng: Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate sadness, give up the six kinds of domestic sadness.

mn137:16.6.pli: Evametesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametesaṃ samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:16.6.eng: That’s how they are given up.

mn137:16.7.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yā cha nekkhammasitā upekkhā tā nissāya tā āgamma, yā cha gehasitā upekkhā tā pajahatha tā samatikkamatha.
mn137:16.7.eng: Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate equanimity, give up the six kinds of domestic equanimity.

mn137:16.8.pli: Evametāsaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametāsaṃ samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:16.8.eng: That’s how they are given up.

mn137:16.9.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāni cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni tāni nissāya tāni āgamma yāni cha nekkhammasitāni domanassāni tāni pajahatha, tāni samatikkamatha.
mn137:16.9.eng: Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate happiness, give up the six kinds of renunciate sadness.

mn137:16.10.pli: Evametesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametesaṃ samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:16.10.eng: That’s how they are given up.

mn137:16.11.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yā cha nekkhammasitā upekkhā tā nissāya tā āgamma yāni cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni tāni pajahatha, tāni samatikkamatha.
mn137:16.11.eng: Therein, by relying on the six kinds of renunciate equanimity, give up the six kinds of renunciate happiness.

mn137:16.12.pli: Evametesaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametesaṃ samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:16.12.eng: That’s how they are given up.

mn137:17.1.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, upekkhā nānattā nānattasitā, atthi upekkhā ekattā ekattasitā.
mn137:17.1.eng: There is equanimity that is diversified, based on diversity, and equanimity that is unified, based on unity.

mn137:18.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, upekkhā nānattā nānattasitā?
mn137:18.1.eng: And what is equanimity based on diversity?

mn137:18.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, upekkhā rūpesu, atthi saddesu, atthi gandhesu, atthi rasesu, atthi phoṭṭhabbesu—
mn137:18.2.eng: There is equanimity towards sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

mn137:18.3.eng: This is equanimity based on diversity.

mn137:19.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, upekkhā ekattā ekattasitā?
mn137:19.1.eng: And what is equanimity based on unity?

mn137:19.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, upekkhā ākāsānañcāyatananissitā, atthi viññāṇañcāyatananissitā, atthi ākiñcaññāyatananissitā, atthi nevasaññānāsaññāyatananissitā—
mn137:19.2.eng: There is equanimity based on the dimensions of infinite space, infinite consciousness, nothingness, and neither perception nor non-perception.

mn137:19.3.eng: This is equanimity based on unity.

mn137:20.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ upekkhā ekattā ekattasitā taṃ nissāya taṃ āgamma yāyaṃ upekkhā nānattā nānattasitā taṃ pajahatha, taṃ samatikkamatha.
mn137:20.1.eng: Therein, relying on equanimity based on unity, give up equanimity based on diversity.

mn137:20.2.pli: Evametissā pahānaṃ hoti, evametissā samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:20.2.eng: That’s how it is given up.

mn137:20.3.pli: Atammayataṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya atammayataṃ āgamma yāyaṃ upekkhā ekattā ekattasitā taṃ pajahatha, taṃ samatikkamatha.
mn137:20.3.eng: Relying on not being determined by that, give up equanimity based on unity.

mn137:20.4.pli: Evametissā pahānaṃ hoti, evametissā samatikkamo hoti.
mn137:20.4.eng: That’s how it is given up.

mn137:20.5.eng: ‘Therein, relying on this, give up that.’

mn137:20.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:20.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:21.1.pli: ‘Tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahatī’ti—
mn137:21.1.eng: ‘The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group.’
mn137:21.1.comm: The text has a unique teaching of three satipaṭṭhānas (“establishments of mindfulness”).

mn137:21.3.eng: but why did I say it?

mn137:22.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, satthā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṃ upādāya:
mn137:22.1.eng: The first case is when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:

mn137:22.2.eng: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’

mn137:22.3.pli: Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
mn137:22.3.eng: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.

mn137:22.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, tathāgato na ceva anattamano hoti, na ca anattamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, anavassuto ca viharati sato sampajāno.
mn137:22.4.eng: In this case the Realized One is not unhappy, he does not feel unhappiness. He remains unfestering, mindful and aware.
mn137:22.4.comm: In the Pali manuscripts and commentary, the Burmese manuscripts appear to be alone in having the negative form anattamana (“unhappy”). The Chinese parallel, however, supports the negative form (MA 163 at T i 693c29). | The commentarial derivation of attamana as “self-mind” (= sakamana, “own-mind”) is unsatisfactory. Read with Sanskrit āttamanas or ādattamanas (“uplifted mind”, “smiling mind”).

mn137:22.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahati.
mn137:22.5.eng: This is the first case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness.

mn137:23.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, satthā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṃ upādāya:
mn137:23.1.eng: The next case is when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:

mn137:23.2.eng: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’

mn137:23.3.pli: Tassa ekacce sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti;
mn137:23.3.eng: And some of their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.

mn137:23.4.pli: ekacce sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṃ odahanti, aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti.
mn137:23.4.eng: But some of their disciples do want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.

mn137:23.5.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, tathāgato na ceva anattamano hoti, na ca anattamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
mn137:23.5.eng: In this case the Realized One is not unhappy,

mn137:23.6.pli: na ca attamano hoti, na ca attamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.

mn137:23.8.pli: tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
mn137:23.8.eng: Shunning both unhappiness and happiness, he remains equanimous, mindful and aware.

mn137:23.9.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahati.
mn137:23.9.eng: This is the second case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness.

mn137:24.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, satthā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṃ upādāya:
mn137:24.1.eng: The next case is when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:

mn137:24.2.eng: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’

mn137:24.3.pli: Tassa sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṃ odahanti, aññācittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti.
mn137:24.3.eng: And their disciples want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.

mn137:24.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, tathāgato attamano ceva hoti, attamanatañca paṭisaṃvedeti, anavassuto ca viharati sato sampajāno.
mn137:24.4.eng: In this case the Realized One is happy, he does feel happiness. He remains unfestering, mindful and aware.

mn137:24.5.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahati.
mn137:24.5.eng: This is the third case in which the Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness.

mn137:24.6.pli: ‘Tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahatī’ti—
mn137:24.6.eng: ‘The Noble One cultivates the establishment of mindfulness in three cases, by virtue of which they are a Teacher worthy to instruct a group.’

mn137:24.7.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn137:24.7.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn137:25.1.eng: ‘Of all meditation tutors, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those fit for training.’

mn137:25.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn137:25.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn137:25.3.pli: Hatthidamakena, bhikkhave, hatthidammo sārito ekaṃyeva disaṃ dhāvati—
mn137:25.3.eng: Driven by an elephant trainer, an elephant in training proceeds in just one direction:
mn137:25.3.comm: It seems that the text is punning sārita (“driving”) with sārathi (“charioteer”).

mn137:25.4.pli: puratthimaṃ vā pacchimaṃ vā uttaraṃ vā dakkhiṇaṃ vā.

mn137:26.1.pli: Assadamakena, bhikkhave, assadammo sārito ekaññeva disaṃ dhāvati—
mn137:26.1.eng: Driven by a horse trainer, a horse in training proceeds in just one direction:

mn137:26.2.pli: puratthimaṃ vā pacchimaṃ vā uttaraṃ vā dakkhiṇaṃ vā.

mn137:26.3.pli: Godamakena, bhikkhave, godammo sārito ekaññeva disaṃ dhāvati—
mn137:26.3.eng: Driven by an ox trainer, an ox in training proceeds in just one direction:

mn137:26.4.pli: puratthimaṃ vā pacchimaṃ vā uttaraṃ vā dakkhiṇaṃ vā.

mn137:26.5.pli: Tathāgatena hi, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena purisadammo sārito aṭṭha disā vidhāvati.
mn137:26.5.eng: But driven by the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, a person in training proceeds in eight directions:
mn137:26.5.comm: Here follow the eight liberations, which show the course of practice for realizing the highest form of “equanimity based on unity”.

mn137:27.1.eng: Having physical form, they see forms.

mn137:27.3.eng: Not perceiving physical form internally, they see forms externally.

mn137:27.7.pli: sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn137:27.7.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

mn137:27.9.pli: sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn137:27.9.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

mn137:27.11.pli: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn137:27.11.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

mn137:27.13.pli: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn137:27.13.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn137:27.15.pli: sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati—
mn137:27.15.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

mn137:27.17.pli: Tathāgatena, bhikkhave, arahatā sammāsambuddhena purisadammo sārito imā aṭṭha disā vidhāvati.
mn137:27.17.eng: Driven by the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, a person in training proceeds in these eight directions.

mn137:28.1.eng: ‘Of all meditation tutors, it is he that is called the supreme guide for those fit for training.’

mn137:28.2.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
mn137:28.2.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

mn137:28.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn137:28.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn137:28.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
